text:
Shore Boulevard, east side, north of 21st Ave., showing the home of Mrs. Polhemus in 1852. This is an 18th Century structure. In the rear of this house is hte Rapelje family’s burial place. the history of this farmland begins with a land grant in 1653 to Teunis Craye. In 1681 Hendrick Martense Wiltsee (a Dane) purchased it. He in turn conveyed it in 1706 to his son, Teunis Wiltsee. This house was erected by Jacob Rapelje who was born in 1714. His daughter married Abraham Polhemus; then this house acquired its name. This is a set of three views. This house is now on land belonging to the Consolidated Gas Company.
1922
View 2: June 1925.
View 3: 1922.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

Shore Boulevard (foreground, not shown), east side, between Twentyfirst Ave. (left) and Ditmars Boulevard, showing in a set of four views the Nesbitt house from 1859 to 1873. Also known as the Nesmith house. Views 3 and 4 are rear views. In 1928 it occupied lot 202 in block 896.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Shore Boulevard (foreground, not shown), east side, between Twentyfirst Ave. (left) and Ditmars Boulevard, showing in a set of four views the Nesbitt house from 1859 to 1873. Also known as the Nesmith house. Views 3 and 4 are rear views. In 1928 it occupied lot 202 in block 896.

Shore Boulevard (left foreground, not shown), east side, between Twenty-first Ave. (left) and Ditmars Boulevard, showing the Nesbitt house in a set of two views. See other views for more data.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Shore Boulevard (left foreground, not shown), east side, between Twenty-first Ave. (left) and Ditmars Boulevard, showing the Nesbitt house in a set of two views. See other views for more data.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Shore Boulevard, north from 21st Ave., showing in the foreground (partially seen) the home of Abraham Polhemus; in the background is that of Jerome S. Polhemus.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(2)
The same, showing a close up of A. Polhemus' farmhouse, and a gas tank of the Consolidated Gas Company upon whose land the house now stands. Note,history has it that Richard Berrien bought in 1737 the land with a house thereon. Jacob Rapelje the next owner built the present home.
March 1923.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(3)
The same, a slightly different angle.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(4)
The same, another angle.
June 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

Shore Boulevard (foreground), at the N.E. corner of Twenty-first Ave. This was the home of James S. Polhemus from 1852-1860.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

(1)
Shore Boulevard (right), south of 2lst Ave., showing in the background (right) the former home of A. D. Ditmar and beyond it the New York Connecting Railroad Bridge. In the foreground is the Nesbit house.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, viewed from 2lst Ave. This bridge was designed by Gustave Lindenthal and opened on April 1, 1917. The cost was over ~12,000,000. The steel arches rise 220 feet and have a clear span between abutments of about 1000 feet.
June 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Shore Boulevard (right), south of 2lst Ave., showing in the background (right) the former home of A. D. Ditmar and beyond it the New York Connecting Railroad Bridge. In the foreground is the Nesbit house.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

21st Avenue, adjoining the N. E. corner of Shore Boulevwrd, showing the house which belonged to Polhemus in 1873. The view is forth from Shore Boulevard across 21st Avenue, which
was formely known as Wolcott Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  Pebruary 9, 1932
